articles.headline: Time for Regulators to Impose Order in the Markets
articles.snippet: As competition between exchanges and computerized trading has surged, it has become harder to prevent problems like the May 6 frenzy.
articles.abstract: As competition between exchanges and computerized trading has surged, it has become harder to prevent problems like the May 6 frenzy.
articles.lead_paragraph: If your machine makes a mistake that the dumbest human would never make, then maybe you don’t have a very good machine.

articles.headline: Online Talk, Suicides and a Thorny Court Case
articles.snippet: A Minnesota man is facing charges of aiding in the suicides of two people by encouraging them online.
articles.abstract: A Minnesota man is facing charges of aiding in the suicides of two people by encouraging them online.
articles.lead_paragraph: The seemingly empathetic nurse struck up conversations over the Internet with people who were pondering suicide. She told them what methods worked best. She told some that it was all right to let go, that they would be better in heaven, and entered into suicide pacts with others.

articles.headline: U.S. Approval of Killing of Cleric Causes Unease
articles.snippet: The notion that the government can execute an American-born cleric far from a combat zone, with no judicial process, has set off a debate among authorities.
articles.abstract: The notion that the government can execute an American-born cleric far from a combat zone, with no judicial process, has set off a debate among authorities.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Obama administration’s decision to authorize the killing by the Central Intelligence Agency of a terrorism suspect who is an American citizen has set off a debate over the legal and political limits of drone missile strikes, a mainstay of the campaign against terrorism.

articles.headline: With Banks Under Fire, Some Expect a Settlement
articles.snippet: As half a dozen government agencies try to determine which bank, if any, broke the rules, some legal experts are handicapping the chances of a settlement.
articles.abstract: As half a dozen government agencies try to determine which bank, if any, broke the rules, some legal experts are handicapping the chances of a settlement.
articles.lead_paragraph: It is starting to feel as if everyone on Wall Street is under investigation by someone for something.
articles.byline: By Nelson D. Schwartz and Eric Dash

articles.headline: Boulder, Colo., a Magnet for High-Tech Start-Ups
articles.snippet: Boulder, Colo., in the foothills of the Rocky Mountains, has become a magnet for entrepreneurs seeking to start technology companies.
articles.abstract: Boulder, Colo., in the foothills of the Rocky Mountains, has become a magnet for entrepreneurs seeking to start technology companies.
articles.lead_paragraph: BOULDER, Colo. — Sixty engineers, entrepreneurs and financiers were sipping yerba mate tea at a coffee shop down the street from a bong-and-lingerie store on a recent sunny Tuesday in Boulder, and discussing how Boulder — usually seen as an enclave of hippies, marijuana dispensaries and rock climbers — has become a hotbed of capitalism.

articles.headline: Size of Oil Spill Underestimated, Scientists Say
articles.snippet: The government and BP used improper measuring techniques, scientists and environmental groups say.
articles.abstract: The government and BP used improper measuring techniques, scientists and environmental groups say.
articles.lead_paragraph: Two weeks ago, the government put out a round estimate of the size of the oil leak in the Gulf of Mexico: 5,000 barrels a day. Repeated endlessly in news reports, it has become conventional wisdom.

articles.headline: In India, Hitching Hopes on a Subway
articles.snippet: The Delhi Metro offers new hope that the nation’s decrepit urban infrastructure can be dragged into the 21st century.
articles.abstract: The Delhi Metro offers new hope that the nation’s decrepit urban infrastructure can be dragged into the 21st century.
articles.lead_paragraph: NEW DELHI — The trains arrive with a whisper. The doors slide open and a puff of refrigerated air confronts the city’s summertime miasma. A bell dings, the doors close and the train whisks its passengers to the next stop.

articles.headline: U.S. Said to Allow Drilling Without Needed Permits
articles.snippet: The federal Minerals Management Service gave permission to dozens of oil  companies to drill in the Gulf of Mexico without first getting required permits from another agency.
articles.abstract: The federal Minerals Management Service gave permission to dozens of oil  companies to drill in the Gulf of Mexico without first getting required permits from another agency.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The federal Minerals Management Service gave permission to BP and dozens of other oil companies to drill in the Gulf of Mexico without first getting required permits from another agency that assesses threats to endangered species — and despite strong warnings from that agency about the impact the drilling was likely to have on the gulf.

articles.headline: Cellphones Now Used More for Data Than for Calls
articles.snippet: The growth in voice minutes has stagnated, while the volume of text messages and other data has soared.
articles.abstract: The growth in voice minutes has stagnated, while the volume of text messages and other data has soared.
articles.lead_paragraph: Liza Colburn uses her cellphone constantly.

articles.headline: Lifesaving Devices Can Cause Havoc at Life’s End
articles.snippet: The medical community has begun to consider policies about when to turn off a heart defibrillator that might cause pain to a dying patient.
articles.abstract: The medical community has begun to consider policies about when to turn off a heart defibrillator that might cause pain to a dying patient.
articles.lead_paragraph: When her father’s cancer became terminal, Carol Filak realized that making his final days comfortable involved something she had never thought about — turning off his heart defibrillator.

articles.headline: Wall St. Slides, Fearing Return to a Recession
articles.snippet: Investors appeared worried that the problems in Europe could begin to drag the global economy back toward recession.
articles.abstract: Investors appeared worried that the problems in Europe could begin to drag the global economy back toward recession.
articles.lead_paragraph: Investors, who had started the week reassured by the huge rescue of Europe’s indebted nations, expressed second thoughts on Friday, sending markets lower and further devaluing the euro on concerns that the austerity measures required by the bailout would stunt the Continent’s already anemic economic growth.
